key_insight: Standard psychometric tests can be adapted to reliably measure personality-like traits in instruction-tuned LLMs, and those trait profiles can be induced and validated in downstream tasks.
problem_solved: Addresses the lack of a validated, systematic framework for quantifying and shaping 'personality' in LLMs—moving beyond ad hoc or anecdotal assessments to reproducible psychometric evaluation and control.
method: Adapt established psychometric instruments (e.g., Big Five questionnaires) into promptable formats for LLM responses.
Evaluate measurement quality with psychometric analyses (reliability, factor structure, convergent/discriminant validity) across model families and settings.
Shape or induce target personality profiles via conditioning/instruction-tuning and test transferability in downstream tasks.
impact: Provides AI practitioners a reproducible toolkit for evaluating, customizing, and validating model personas—enabling controlled behavior design, better user experience, and more rigorous alignment/evaluation pipelines.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: 'Psychometric instrument → Prompting & response collection → Reliability/validity analysis → Persona induction & downstream transfer'.
Radar/spider chart comparing Big Five trait scores across multiple LLMs and tuning methods.
Bar chart or table showing reliability metrics (e.g., Cronbach's alpha) and factor loadings for tests across models.
Before/after examples: prompt + model response illustrating persona induction and a downstream-task performance comparison.
paper_title: A psychometric framework for evaluating and shaping personality traits in large language models
paper_authors: Gregory Serapio-García, Mustafa Safdari, Clément Crepy, Luning Sun, Stephen Fitz
